mdRecord.dcterms:title: Letter, Thomas Law to John Law, 1804 September 25
mdRecord.dcterms:creator: Law, Thomas, 1756-1834
mdRecord.dcterms:description: Thomas Law's response to September 14th letter, pleased his son visited Mr. Carroll - Mr. and Mrs. Harper. Reports death of Mrs. Williams and the settlement of her estate. Ms. Gallatin is in Washington - the President is expected soon. Appreciates his son's sentiments towards his estranged wife Mrs. Law, has regrets over their painful separation. Encloses 40 dollars and will look over papers for son's 'nativity' claiming he is about 20 years of age. Returned from a visit to Mr. William Brent at Mrs. Diggs's. Heard from his brother Ewan, all relations are well. Concerned about the well being of Great Britain with Napoleon's dominance, quotes infamous motto -oderint dum metuant. Dined with Marquis Yrujo (Spanish Minister) and noted the embarrassing publication of the diplomat's interview with William Jackson. Playhouse to open soon; hopes to see advancement in promoting city. Advises son to get into the habit of writing down items to attend to - become more methodical. Autograph letter signed, 3 pages, integral address panel with broken (red) wax seal.
